PROJECT LABEL (Required): A short name for the project.
PROJECT TITLE (Required): An official title for the project.
PROJECT DESCRIPTION (Required): A longer description of the project which includes research goals and experimental approach.
SUPPLEMENTARY LINK(S): External link(s) pointing to code, supplementary data files, or analysis files associated with the project which will not be uploaded.
INSDC PROJECT ACCESSION: An International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC) project accession.
GEO SERIES ACCESSION: A Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) series accession.
INSDC STUDY ACCESSION: An International Nucleotide Sequence Database Collaboration (INSDC) study accession.

PROJECT LABEL (Required): Project label is a short label by which you refer to the project. It should have no spaces and should be fewer than 50 characters. For example: CoolOrganProject.
PROJECT TITLE (Required): Project title should be fewer than 30 words, such as a title of a grant proposal or a publication. For example: Study of single cells in the human body.
PROJECT DESCRIPTION (Required): Project description should be fewer than 300 words, such as an abstract from a grant application or publication.
INSDC PROJECT ACCESSION: Enter accession if project has been archived. Accession can be from the DDBJ, NCBI, or EMBL-EBI and must start with DRP, SRP, or ERP, respectively. For example: SRP000000
GEO SERIES ACCESSION: Enter accession if project has been archived. Accession must start with GSE. For example: GSE00000
ARRAYEXPRESS ACCESSION: Enter accession if project has been archived. Accession must start with E-. For example: E-AAAA-00
INSDC STUDY ACCESSION: Enter accession if study has been archived. Accession can be from the DDBJ, NCBI, or EMBL-EBI and must start with PRJD, PRJN, or PRJE, respectively. For example: PRJNA000000
BIOSTUDIES ACCESSION: Enter accession if study has been archived. For example: S-EXMP1; S-HCAS33

PROJECT LABEL (Required): FILL OUT INFORMATION BELOW THIS ROW

PROJECT TITLE (Required): Spatio-temporal immune zonation of the human kidney
PROJECT DESCRIPTION (Required): Tissue-resident immune cells are important for organ homeostasis and defense. The epithelium may contribute to these functions directly, or via crosstalk with immune cells. We resolved the spatio-temporal immune topology of the human kidney with a scRNAseq dataset from 40,268 mature and 27,203 fetal kidney cells. Within the epithelial compartment there were zonated patterns of immune gene expression, with pelvic epithelial anti-microbial peptide expression in mature but not fetal kidneys. Tissue-resident immune cells were evident in both fetal and mature kidney, with post-natal acquisition of infection-defense capabilities. Epithelial-immune signalling orchestrated localization of macrophages and neutrophils to regions of the kidney susceptible to infection.
